Award.AwardTitle: 2018 and 2019 US Ignite Application Summits - Bridging Academic Research and Community Stakeholders for Increased Impact

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
US Ignite Application Summits in 2018 and 2019 will create a public forum for demonstration of advanced applications that are designed to take advantage of next-generation networking technology. The Summits will serve to illustrate the important role that advanced networks play in the emerging smart and connected communities / Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem and provide a unique opportunity to facilitate partnerships among university-based researchers, industry and community leaders. The applications that will be showcased as part of the summit will also demonstrate how advanced networking technologies support economic growth and prosperity, improvement of quality of lives and delivery of healthcare services.


The US Ignite Application Summits in 2018 and 2019 will also complement the Smart and Connected Community program. By co-locating the Application Summit with the NSF Smart and Connected Community (S&CC) program principal investigators' (PI) meeting, there will be increased opportunity for transition of technologies to communities as well as additional insights into both community needs and the state of the art in smart applications and S&CC PI research. The Application Summits will also provide a venue for community leaders spanning rural and urban regions of various size to interact with application developers and researchers in panel discussions, poster sessions, and technology demonstrations. They will also give exposure to applications that other local governments and their project partners have developed, and enhance opportunities to transfer research products across communities. The Application Summits in 2018 and 2019 will serve to build research capacity by disseminating information, lessons learned and best practices across the research community and its partners in municipal government.

POR.DRECONTENT:
US Ignite, in collaboration with Smart Cities Connect, hosted the 2018 US Ignite Application Summit from March 27-29 2018 in Kansas City, Missouri, and the 2019 US Ignite Application Summit from April 2-4, 2019 in Denver, Colorado. The events served as opportunities to learn, share, and celebrate next-generation smart and connected community applications and services and share experiences with stakeholders from across US Ignite’s communities, including cities, states, regions, and military bases.

Over 3,100 individuals across a broad range of organizations, including academia, research labs, universities, corporations, non-profit entities, and municipal governments, convened to explore and discuss the real-world benefits of advanced networking technologies and next-generation applications and services that will help transform our communities with better healthcare, education, public safety, transportation, and clean energy.

The major goals of the 2018 and 2019 US Ignite Application Summits were to:

  • Create a public forum for demonstration of advanced applications that are designed to take advantage of next generation networking technology;
  • Demonstrate the important role that advanced networks play in the emerging smart and connected communities/Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystems and illustrate the importance of partnerships among university-based researchers, industry and municipal leaders; and,
  • Open lines of communication and showcase opportunities for collaboration between research communities and local, state and federal government stakeholders related to the goals of the NSF Smart and Connected Communities (S&CC) program.

The 2018 and 2019 US Ignite Application Summits each provided two full days of education and learning for participants. Highlights of the US Ignite Application Summits included:

2018 US Ignite Application Summit

  • Dr. Jim Kurose, Assistant Director of the National Science Foundation (NSF) for Computer and Information Science and Engineering provided a keynote on PAWRing Smart and Connected Communities: Driving Research and Impact. 
  • Mark Farrell, Mayor of the City and County of San Francisco presented on the Fiber for San Francisco, Internet for All initiative.
  • Six collaborative stage demonstrations, including SONYC: Cyber-Physical Noise Monitoring and Analysis, Low-Cost Sensing of Pollution Variation within Communities, Smart and Connected Energy-Aware Residential Communities, CityGuide: Beacon-Based Community-Driven Inclusive Wayfinding, Visualizing Underground Infrastructure in Augmented Reality, and Smart Stormwater Systems were presented on stage.
  • 30+ demonstrations representing researchers and cities across the world were showcased on the expo floor.
  • US Ignite Welcomed the newest Smart Gigabit Communities (SGCs), including Eugene-Springfield, Oregon; Lexington; Kentucky; Lincoln, Nebraska; Red Wing, Minnesota; Adelaide, Australia; Las Vegas, Nevada; and San Francisco Bay Area, California.
  • A plenary panel discussion that included both researchers and community partners supported by the NSF S&CC program.

2019 US Ignite Application Summit

  • Dr. Erwin Gianchandani, Deputy Assistant Director for the Directorate of Computer and Information Science and Engineering provided a keynote on PAWR and the launch of the POWDER testbed.
  • Michael Hancock, Mayor of Denver welcomed attendees to the City of Denver.
  • Dereck Orr, Division Chief of the Public Safety Communications Division, National Institute of Standards and Technology discussed R&D funding opportunities around public safety.
  • Seven collaborative stage demonstrations, including Live 360 VR Video for STEM Education, Resilient Water Systems, iNotify, Grounding the Cloud in Community, Real-Time Drone Streaming, GonioSense, and Cipher were presented on stage.
  • 35+ demonstrations representing researchers and cities across the world were showcased on the expo floor.
  • US Ignite shared important PAWR and Forum updates and also announced the induction of several new communities into the SGC project: Vaughan, Canada,  St. Petersburg, Florida, and Colorado Springs, Colorado.
  • US Ignite also convened three afternoon panels, including: Building a Smart Base and Community, Building Network Infrastructure for the 5G Future, and Activating your Smart Regional Community and Getting Community Buy-In.
  • The SGC project team convened a 3.5-hour session, titled Accelerating the Smart City Movement: Research & Innovation for Community Impact. The purpose of this session was to convene SGC stakeholders from across the world to address smart city and IoT challenges.
  • More than 75 (out of 231 attendees that registered through US Ignite) of the US Ignite Application Summit participants were female participants, persons with disabilities, and underrepresented minorities in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). 

Looking ahead to the 2020 Application Summit in National Harbor (November 17-19 2020), US Ignite will take the smart community movement one step further yet again. US Ignite will provide a space for discussion, collaboration, and community-building by guiding communities into the connected future, creating a path for private and public sector growth, and advancing technology research that is at the heart of smart city development.
